commit_message:
Flatten exceptions used in policy tests

The policy tests are meant to check if certain roles are properly
enforced by our policy engine. To do this we use the standard
controllers and force an exception in the actual code, just after we
have actually passed the policy.

The code was actually doing what it intended to do, in an unintended
way. By passing the "external_project_id" to the
on_[get|post|delete|put] it was finally getting a TypeError when it
would try to execute the actual code. This was unexpected and
confusing.

The intent of this CR is to get rid of the aforementioned behaviour and
instead force an IOError whenever possible (either by accessing certain
functions, or when trying to access the body of the request).

subject: Fix issue with dependencies of the package
Define TRACE logging level
commit_message:
Define TRACE logging level

TRACE is a logging keyword that is understood by most logging
tools. OpenStack has repurposed this in the past to not be TRACE
logging but instead be used whenever a Stacktrace was dumped. This
was already fixed in:
I8c618e7b8523bcc0e19a9b77c4d2d5984369a04a

Now in this review, we are adding a new TRACE level set to an
integer halfway between DEBUG and NOTSET which is currently 5.

One can also use LOG.trace for deep tracing of their code as well.
To make it easy for end users to import the TRACE level, added
public constants for all the log levels from logging module. Several
projects import logging just for the constants, this will help
them as well.

Please see the logging guidelines for more info:
https://github.com/openstack/openstack-specs/blob/master/specs/log-guidelines.rst

commit_message:
Add support for force-delete backups

1. Add _get and _delete method to BackupAdminController.
2. Add force=False arg to delete method in backup api.

can be in any state.

object in the object store.

indicates if the backup driver supports force deletion.
It should be set to True if the driver that inherits from BackupDriver
supports the force deletion function.

405 when calling API of force delete.

subject: Add Gunicorn
commit_message:
Add Gunicorn

This patch adds Gunicorn to the global dependencies. It's used in Kuryr
to serve a libnetwork remote driver through a Unix domain socket [1].
Originally uWSGI was a candidate but it's released under GPLv2 and
Gunicorn's license is MIT License.

Check list for new requirements:

* Is the library actively maintained?

  Yes. The last commit was made 10 days ago and it's been released
  frequently since 2010 [2].

* Is the library good code?

  Yes. It was downloaded 304,698 times in the last month [3].

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

  Yes. Python 3.x >= 3.2 is required.

* Is the library license compatible?

  Yes. It's released under MIT License.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

  Ubuntu 14.04LTS trusy has a package which version is 17.5 [4] and RHEL6
  does 18.0 [5].

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

  I don't think so.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204820/
[2]: http://docs.gunicorn.org/en/latest/news.html
[3]: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/gunicorn/
[4]: http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/gunicorn
[5]: http://rpms.famillecollet.com/rpmphp/zoom.php?rpm=python-gunicorn

Change-Id: I175893fbffaba6be2089df15b25b7bd31d5d0213

subject: Introduce RPC tests
commit_message:
Introduce RPC tests

The only place we test the interaction between agents and the controller
is in Tempest. These are however 'heavy' tests and are very high level.
There are features that aren't tested in Tempest (Due to no multi node testing
or for other reasons) that have coverage for each individual component but
not for how they interact. In-tree full-stack testing will mitigate this,
but like Tempest, it is too high level as basic RPC interaction can be tested
at a lower level.

The idea is to use the fake Oslo messaging driver (Which is already being
used every where) but to take care not to  mock out critical bits. The fake
driver simply passes messages around in-process without the use of an external
messaging service. The server RPC handlers are already being tested,
so there's no need to test them again. The Oslo messaging driver is not under
test either. So what is being tested? These sort of RPC tests just call an RPC
method from a client, without mocking anything. If the RPC method is expected
to return something, that should be asserted as well.

These tests can catch regressions such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1414812

Future work in dependent patches:
* Complete coverage for all RPC methods.
* Mock heavy unit tests that assert that True == True may now be replaced.
* Rolling upgrades cannot be tested via this framework, but via something
  similar to grenade, which Nova always runs with Nova network. I hope
  to look into running it with Neutron as well.

These tests may be run (On your laptop) with:
tox -e functional neutron.tests.functional.api.rpc

This patch includes RPC tests for the agent report_state and
L3 agent methods just so we can be sure the RPC testing framework
provides sufficient functionality for different RPC endpoints.

Change-Id: I7b15f15f69acf2fc4e01e754f6490cdbb37b453e

subject: Neutron pydevd debugger support
commit_message:
Neutron pydevd debugger support

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and having the
Neutron process connect back to it.

The implementation is similar to the one found in the Keystone or glance
project.

Four configuration options have been added:

    pydev-debug-host <host>. Default is None
    pydev-debug-port <port>. Default is None
    standard-threads (bool): Do not monkey-patch threading system modules.
    no-standard-threads (bool): inverse of --standard-threads. This is the
                             default behavior.

The behavior is enabled if `pydev-debug-host` *and* `pydev-debug-port` are
both not None.

Example:

1. neutron connecting back to pydevd using standard threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 12345

2. neutron connection back to pydevd using patched threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 12345 --no-standard-threads

If the behavior is enabled, an os.environ variable will be set to indicate
that the thread must not get monkey patched:
(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000794.html).
Then, the pydev connection will be performed by the server right when starting
after reading the configuration.

Minor modifications were required to deal with the multiple calls to the
eventlet monkey patcher in multiple places throughout the Neutron code: a new
module in common has been defined performing the actual patch and
checking if whether or not standard threads are in use to discard thread patch
calls. Calls to eventlet monkey patcher have been changed to leverage this new
module throughout the Neutron code.

`standard-threads` option can be enabled independently of the pydev debug
options using the configuration options or by simply setting up an
environment variable called `STANDARD_THREADS`.

If the pydev connection fails to be established with the remote debugger an
exception is raised.

This patch will allow remote debugging as well as more seamless debugging
environments with IDEs not compatible with patched threads.

Change-Id: Idd4485b405cf0707781aa1250819a2140ee74550

subject: Handle attempts to "filter" list() calls by globally unique IDs
commit_message:
Handle attempts to "filter" list() calls by globally unique IDs

This use case isn't covered by our current APIs:

  GET /entities?id={entity_id}

Because we have a dedicated API for that:

  GET /entities/{entity_id}

But our list() methods generally support **kwargs, which are passed as
query parameters to keystone. When an 'id' is passed to keystone as a
query parameter, keystone rightly ignores it and returns an unfiltered
collection.

To provide the expected user experience, this change swaps calls like
list(id=...) with [get(id)] instead, which calls the correct HTTP API.

subject: Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/
commit_message:
Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/

Angular code for openstack_dashboard is almost finished
migrating to openstack_dashboard/static/app/.

Previously, the root module of app (app.module.js) was explicitly
included from _conf.html so that environment variables from Django
could be captured in the 'horizon.app.conf' constant.

This prevented auto-collection at the static/app/ level because
app.module.js will be included twice (once from _conf.html, and
again during auto-collection)

It turns out that 'horizon.app.conf' is unnecessary as an Angular
constant. It's only use is to initialize the 'horizon.conf' global
provided by horizon.js.

This patch refactors _conf.html to directly initialize horizon.conf.
This removes the need for app.module.js to be included from
_conf.html, which allows us to change the auto-collection directory
to 'app/'.

Now all files in horizon/static and openstack_dashboard/static/app
are auto-collected, without including app.module.js twice. All new
angular files are expected to live in one of these two locations,
minimizing changes to static_settings.py to include new files for
auto-collection

Change-Id: I95b6f13c85eb08c875885812a7db054a5aa6e7c2
Partial-Bug: #1458697
Closes-Bug: #1477825

subject: libvirt: Enhance iSCSI volume multipath support
commit_message:
libvirt: Enhance iSCSI volume multipath support

Currently, nova-compute supports multipath for iSCSI volume data
path. It depends on response to targets discovery from the main
iSCSI portal, expecting multiple portal addresses to be contained.

However, some arrays only respond to discovery with a single portal
address, even if secondary portals are available. In this case,
nova-compute cannot know secondary portals and corresponding iSCSI
target IQN, so nova-compute cannot establish multiple sessions for
the target(s). To enable nova-compute to login to secondary portals,
Cinder's response to initialize_connection API will return
connection_info with multiple portal addresses/iqns/luns when
multipath=True is specifed in the connector info. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portals": ["10.0.2.15:3260", "10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqns": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
                            "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_luns": [1, 2],
            ...}}

Nova should try to login to every portal addresses/iqns/luns when
they are passed from cinder.

Change-Id: Iddd67d6b5b27ccc1e0a3963cbf7896b60da30b01
Implements: blueprint iscsi-multipath-enhancement

subject: Cluster instances could falsely report 'ready'
commit_message:
Cluster instances could falsely report 'ready'

The check used by all cluster strategies is wrong. It allows for both
RUNNING and BUILD_PENDING. All cluster strategies use BUILD_PENDING to
indicate that the instances are cluster-prepare ready. RUNNING is bad as
it can be reported before the instance's prepare even starts, causing
the cluster-prepare to start too early and fail.

The fix is to remove RUNNING from the list of cluster-ready states. It
has been verified that all datastores  set instances to BUILD_PENDING
when used for clusters.

Change-Id: I048e2b76fda59a25928c6c6d3751235df12d7369
Closes-bug: #1478603

more meaningful make the update.py script return something that's more
user friendly.

Version change for: mox, mox3, testrepository, testtools

    mox==0.5.3                     ->   mox>=0.5.3

was largely impossible to make sense of, and rarely provided any
insight. During a devstack run you'll have git hashes for all the
trees, so can track down exact file contents if needed.

the git commit messages.

column limit for the expected blocks via #noqa.

subject: Add handoff region affinity support to replicators
commit_message:
Add handoff region affinity support to replicators

During the Ops Feedback session at the Vancouver summit one feature
request was the ability for swift to attempt to find handoff nodes
close (same region) as the failed primary node.

The proxy already has write affinity which does this. But the
replicators do not. Swift already, when searching for handoff nodes,
tries to keep objects dispersed, so this option is turned off by
default and should only activated if you really want swift to try
and find a handoff node in the same region as the failed node.

This change adds a new parameter to
{object,container,account}-replicator sections of the server
configurations. This parameter is 'handoff_affinity' and defaults
to 0. This number, like in write_affinity, is the number of handoff
nodes to try in the same region as the failed primary node before
falling back to finding a handoff node elsewhere in the cluster.

Because the handoff nodes may (if activated) be determined by the
primary node failing the replication algorithm in the db_replicator
and object replicator has changed slightly. Instead of trying the
primary nodes first and on a 507 continuing down the handoff
nodes, it now loops through each primary nodes, if we fail to
replicate due to a 507 start looking for a handoff node to place
it on before going to the next primary node.

This is a attempt 1, and am sure there will be many other iterations
coming, let the reviews commence!
